FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Simple Suitability
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Simple Suitability - Non Zero Count
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function, hits are only counted on non-zero elements.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Simple Suitability - Zero Focused
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function, only focusing on minimising expected 0 values.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function that includes pressure to reduce the size of algorithms and circuits produced that is sensitive to incorrect phases

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Polar Scaled by 2
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: Fitness function that is is phase sensitive but uses scaling factor, 2, to prioritise the magnitude over the phase.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Polar Scaled by 3
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: Fitness function that is is phase sensitive but uses scaling factor, 3, to prioritise the magnitude over the phase.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Polar Scaled by 4
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: Fitness function that is is phase sensitive but uses scaling factor, 4, to prioritise the magnitude over the phase.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Polar Scaled by 5
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: Fitness function that is is phase sensitive but uses scaling factor, 5, to prioritise the magnitude over the phase.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Non Zero Count
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function that is sensitive to incorrect phases and only counts "hits" on non zero elements

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - Zero Focused
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A phase aware fitness function, only focusing on minimising expected 0 values.

FitnessFunctionTag.Name: Phase Sensitive Suitability - No Count
FitnessFunctionTag.Desc: A simple and naive fitness function that is sensitive to incorrect phases and with no "hit" count
